questions.text: In carotid body glomus cells, hypoxia-induced inhibition of which ion channel is the primary initiating event that triggers neurotransmitter release and increased ventilation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Oxygen sensing in peripheral chemoreceptors (carotid and aortic bodies) begins with the inhibition of oxygen-sensitive K⁺ channels in glomus cells.

Mechanism of Oxygen Sensing:

  • K⁺ Channels
    • Under normoxia, K⁺ channels maintain cell hyperpolarisation.
    • Hypoxia inhibits these channels → depolarisation of the glomus cell membrane.
  • Depolarisation Cascade
    • Depolarisation opens voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels.
    • Influx of Ca²⁺ causes neurotransmitter release (ATP, acetylcholine).
  • Physiological Response
    • Neurotransmitters stimulate afferent nerve endings → respiratory centres.
    • This increases ventilation, restoring oxygen homeostasis.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Voltage-gated calcium channels (Option A): Activated after depolarisation; essential for neurotransmitter release but not the primary hypoxia sensor.

Voltage-gated sodium channels (Option C): Important in action potential generation, but not directly involved in oxygen sensing.

Chloride channels (Option D): Not involved in carotid body chemoreceptor oxygen sensing

Key Takeaway:

Functions of Potassium Ions (K⁺):

  • Maintain resting membrane potential → cellular excitability.
  • Crucial in nerve transmission and muscle contraction (repolarisation phase).
  • Regulate fluid & electrolyte balance, acid-base balance, and kidney function.

Reference: PMC Article: Oxygen Sensing Mechanisms

questions.text: A 70-kg individual has a measured oxygen consumption rate of 750 ml/min while performing a moderate activity. The resting oxygen consumption is considered to be 250 ml/min. What is the MET score for this activity?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

MET (Metabolic Equivalent of Task) is a unit used to estimate energy expenditure during physical activity, defined as the ratio of metabolic rate during activity to resting metabolic rate.

Formula to Calculate MET:

MET=Oxygen consumption during exercise/ Resting oxygen consumption

Given:

  • Oxygen consumption during exercise = 750 ml/min
  • Resting oxygen consumption = 250 ml/min

Calculation:

MET=750  ml/min/ 250  ml/min= 3

Thus, the MET score is 3, indicating that the energy expenditure during exercise is 3 times higher than at rest.

Factors affecting MET:

  • Body weight: Heavier individuals generally have a higher absolute energy expenditure during physical activities than lighter individuals.
  • Fitness level: More physically fit tend to have a more efficient cardiovascular system and improved oxygen utilization, resulting in lower energy expenditure for the same activity than individuals with lower fitness levels.
  • Age: Generally, younger individuals have a higher metabolic rate and may expend more energy during physical activities than older individuals.
  • Activity duration and intensity: Longer durations or higher intensity activities result in higher energy expenditure.
  • Body composition: Individuals with a higher percentage of lean muscle mass typically have a higher metabolic rate and may expend more energy during physical activities.
  • Environmental factors: Extreme temperatures or high altitudes can increase the body's energy demands, leading to higher energy expenditure and potentially higher MET values.

Reference:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2204507/

questions.text: Determine the respiratory quotient (RQ) of a patient weighing 60 kg who exhales 300 ml/min of CO2 and consumes 400 ml/min of O2.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

To determine the respiratory quotient (RQ), we use the formula:

  • RQ = VCO2/VO2
  • Given the values: CO2 exhaled (VCO2) = 300 ml/min
    • O2 consumed (VO2) = 400 ml/min
  • Substituting these values into the formula:
  • RQ = 300 ml/min / 400 ml/min RQ = 0.75

Key Takeaway:

  • Respiratory Quotient (RQ) = ratio of CO2 produced to O2 consumed during metabolism.
  • Normal range: 7 - 1.0.
  • Carbohydrates: 0
  • Fats: 7
  • Proteins: 8 - 0.9

Reference:

https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/biochemistry-genetics-and-molecular-biology/respiratory-quotient#:~:text

choices.text: Decreased systemic vascular resistance due to vasodilation
Increased renal sodium and water reabsorption

questions.text: A 24-year-old medical student suddenly stands up after lying down for 30 minutes while studying. Which of the following compensatory responses is most likely to occur first in order to prevent orthostatic hypotension?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Upon standing, venous pooling occurs in the lower extremities → ↓ venous return → ↓ stroke volume → ↓ cardiac output → ↓ arterial pressure.
  • Baroreceptors (carotid sinus, aortic arch) sense the sudden drop in BP → decreased afferent firing → medullary centers activate sympathetic outflow.
  • This causes:
    • ↑ HR (tachycardia) via β1 receptors
    • ↑ cardiac contractility via β1receptors
    • ↑ vasoconstriction of arterioles and venous tone via α1 receptors
  • This rapid sympathetic compensation happens within seconds, making it the first and fastest response.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Decreased systemic vascular resistance due to vasodilation (Option B): Opposite of what occurs; vasoconstriction, not vasodilation, is needed to restore BP.

Increased renal sodium and water reabsorption (Option C): Part of long-term BP regulation (hours to days), mediated by hormones, not an immediate response.

Activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (Option D): Important but slower (minutes to hours), not the immediate first response.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with atrial fibrillation is started on warfarin therapy. Which of the following coagulation factors will be affected first due to their short half-life, leading to early anticoagulant effect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Warfarin inhibits vitamin K epoxide reductase, preventing the recycling of reduced vitamin K.
  • Reduced vitamin K is required for γ-carboxylation of glutamate residues in clotting factors → essential for calcium binding and coagulation.
  • Factors affected: II, VII, IX, X (vitamin K-dependent factors).
  • Also affects anticoagulant proteins C and S.
  • Factor VII has the shortest half-life (~6 hours), so its depletion is seen first, and it explains why PT (prothrombin time/INR) is the earliest affected lab parameter.
  • Factor II (prothrombin) has a much longer half-life (~60-72 hours), so full anticoagulant effect is delayed.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Factor II (Option B): Vitamin K dependent, but long half-life (60-72 hrs), so depletion occurs much later.

Factor IX (Option C): Vitamin K dependent, but half-life is ~24 hrs, not the earliest to be affected.

Factor X (Option D): Also vitamin K dependent, but its half-life is ~40 hrs, slower depletion than Factor VII.

Key Takeaway:

Warfarin Mechanism of action:

choices.text: Hypoventilation due to hypoxic depression of respiratory centers
Hyperventilation due to hypoxic stimulation of peripheral chemoreceptors
Decreased 2,3-BPG production leading to left shift of O2-Hb dissociation curve
Reduced renal bicarbonate reabsorption compensating for alkalosis

questions.text: A 25-year-old mountaineer rapidly ascends to 4000 meters above sea level and develops headache, nausea, and insomnia. Arterial blood gas analysis shows hypoxemia with respiratory alkalosis. Which of the following physiological mechanisms best explains the alkalosis observed in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • At high altitude, low barometric pressure → hypoxemia.
  • Peripheral chemoreceptors (carotid bodies) sense low PaO₂ → stimulate hyperventilation.
  • Hyperventilation → excessive CO₂ washout → respiratory alkalosis.
  • Over several days, kidneys compensate by increasing bicarbonate excretion (metabolic compensation).

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Hypoventilation (Option A): Opposite occurs; hypoxia drives hyperventilation, not depression.

Decreased 2,3-BPG (Option C): Actually, 2,3-BPG increases at high altitude, shifting the O₂ -Hb curve to the right (facilitates O₂ unloading).

Reduced renal bicarbonate reabsorption (Option D): This occurs later (renal compensation), not the immediate cause of alkalosis.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A 56-year-old male with long-standing hypertension undergoes right heart catheterization for evaluation of suspected right-sided heart failure. During the procedure, the pressure tracing from the right atrium shows a positive deflection synchronous with isovolumetric contraction of the right ventricle. This corresponds to which wave of the JVP?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The c wave corresponds to the bulging of the closed tricuspid valve into the right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction, causing a brief rise in right atrial pressure.


Explanation of Incorrect Options:

a wave (Option A): Caused by atrial contraction, not ventricular contraction.

v wave (Option C): Represents passive atrial filling while the tricuspid valve is closed.

y descent (Option D): Represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the ventricle after the tricuspid valve opens.

choices.text: Shift of the end-systolic volume and pressure curves to the right

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with dilated cardiomyopathy is evaluated using echocardiography and pressure-volume loop analysis. The study shows reduced myocardial contractility. Which of the following changes would be most consistent with this finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Decreased contractility reduces the ability of the ventricle to generate pressure at any given volume. On the pressure-volume loop, this is represented by a rightward shift of the end-systolic pressure-volume relationship (ESPVR).

  • This indicates that the ventricle ejects less blood per beat, leading to increased end-systolic volume and reduced stroke volume.

Myocardial Contractility

  • Definition:
    • The intrinsic ability of the myocardium to contract and generate force, independent of preload (end-diastolic volume) and afterload (resistance against which the heart pumps).
    • Changes in contractility shift the Frank-Starling curve (relationship between stroke volume and end-diastolic volume).
  • Impact on Frank-Starling Curve:
    • Increased Contractility (Positive Inotropic Effects):
    • Shifts the curve upward and to the left.
    • Results in a greater stroke volume at any given preload.
    • Decreased Contractility (Negative Inotropic Effects):
    • Shifts the curve downward and to the right.

The Bowditch Effect

  • Alternative Names: Treppe phenomenon, staircase phenomenon, frequency-dependent activation
  • Definition:
  • An increase in heart rate enhances the force of contraction of myocardial cells with each heartbeat, independent of other influences.
  • Mechanism:
  • Related to calcium ion handling and mishandling in cardiac cells.
  • Involves proteins crucial for excitation-contraction coupling, such as sarcoplasmic endoplasmic reticulum calcium-ATPase (SERCA).

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Decreased end-diastolic volume and pressure (Option A): In heart failure with reduced contractility, end-diastolic volume & pressure usually increase, not decrease, due to impaired ejection and higher filling pressures.

Increased stroke volume (Option C): Stroke volume falls with reduced contractility, as less blood is pumped out.

Enhanced response to sympathetic stimulation (Option D): Diseased myocardium shows blunted response to sympathetic stimulation due to receptor downregulation and impaired calcium handling.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537021/

questions.text: Blood pressure changes in the radial artery were measured during a Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following explains the initial rise in blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

At the onset of straining (Phase I) of the Valsalva maneuver, intrathoracic pressure rises sharply due to forced expiration against a closed glottis.

  • This compresses the aorta and large thoracic vessels, leading to a transient rise in arterial pressure (seen at the radial artery).
  • This rise is mechanical, not due to increased stroke volume or cardiac output.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Increase in left ventricular volume (Option A): LV volume actually decreases during strain due to reduced venous return.

Decrease in left ventricular pressure (Option B): LV pressure does not fall in Phase I; the rise in BP is due to external compression, not reduced LV pressure.

Decrease in aortic pressure (Option D): Aortic pressure increases initially (Phase I), then falls during Phase II due to decreased venous return.

Reference: Valsalva Maneuver - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text:
Which of the following statements best describes the mechanism of sneezing?
Statements:
1. Initiated by irritation of the nasal mucosa
2. Involves closure of the glottis followed by forceful expiration
3. Involves forceful expiration against an open glottis
4. Functions to expel irritants from nasal passages
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Initiated by irritation of nasal mucosa (Statement 1):
    • Sneezing reflex is triggered by mechanical/chemical irritation of nasal mucosa (e.g., dust, pollen).
  • Forceful expiration against an open glottis (Statement 3):
    • After deep inspiration, there is forceful expiration with open glottis unlike cough (closed glottis).
  • Expelling irritants from nasal passages (Statement 4):
    • Main protective role of sneezing is to clear nasal passages of irritants.
  • Involves closure of the glottis followed by forceful expiration (Statement 2):
    • Glottis closure (2) occurs in cough, not sneezing.

Thus, statements 1,3,4 describe sneezing correctly.

choices.text: Both ventilation and perfusion increase from apex to base, but perfusion increases more steeply, making V/Q lowest at the apex.
Both ventilation and perfusion decrease from base to apex, but ventilation decreases more steeply, making V/Q lowest at the apex.
Both ventilation and perfusion decrease from base to apex, but perfusion decreases more steeply, making V/Q highest at the apex.
Ventilation remains constant from base to apex, while perfusion declines, making V/Q uniform throughout the lung.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) ratio in the upright lung is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The normal average ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) ratio for the lung is 0.8 (4.2 L/min alveolar ventilation ÷ 5.5 L/min blood flow).
  • In the upright lung, both ventilation and perfusion decrease from the bases to the apices due to gravity.
  • However, perfusion decreases more steeply than ventilation, resulting in:
    • High V/Q ratios at the apex (wasted ventilation, relatively more O2 but less blood flow).
    • Low V/Q ratios at the base (wasted perfusion, relatively more blood flow but less O2).
  • If ventilation falls relative to perfusion → ↓ alveolar PO2, ↑ alveolar PCO2.
  • If perfusion falls relative to ventilation → ↑ alveolar PO2, ↓ alveolar PCO2.
  • Widespread non-uniformity of V/Q ratios leads to CO2 retention and arterial hypoxemia.

Explanation of Other Options:

Both ventilation and perfusion increase from apex to base, but perfusion increases more steeply, making V/Q lowest at the apex (Option A): Incorrect, because V/Q is lowest at the base, not the apex.

Both ventilation and perfusion decrease from base to apex, but ventilation decreases more steeply, making V/Q lowest at the apex (Option B): Incorrect, because perfusion decreases more steeply, not ventilation.

Ventilation remains constant from base to apex, while perfusion declines, making V/Q uniform throughout the lung (Option D): Incorrect, ventilation also declines; V/Q is not uniform.

Key Takeaway:

In the upright lung, both ventilation and perfusion decline from base to apex, but perfusion declines more steeply, resulting in a high V/Q at the apex and a low V/Q at the base.

choices.text: It facilitates the exchange of HCO3- from plasma into RBCs, maintaining osmotic balance.
It results in a higher chloride content in venous RBCs compared to arterial RBCs.
It is mediated by carbonic anhydrase located in the plasma.
It reduces venous hematocrit by causing water efflux from RBCs

questions.text: Which of the following statements best explains the chloride shift in systemic capillaries?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The chloride shift (Hamburger phenomenon) occurs when bicarbonate (HCO3-) formed inside RBCs diffuses into plasma in exchange for chloride ions (Cl-), mediated by the anion exchanger AE1 (Band 3 protein). This exchange maintains electroneutrality.

  • In systemic capillaries, CO2 enters RBCs, rapidly converts to H2CO3 via carbonic anhydrase, and dissociates into H⁺ and HCO3-.
  • H⁺ is buffered by deoxyhemoglobin, while HCO3- exits the RBC in exchange for Cl-.
  • As a result, the chloride content of venous RBCs is significantly greater than that of arterial RBCs.
  • This process is rapid (completed within ~1 s) and ensures efficient CO2 transport.
  • The osmotically active particles (HCO3- or Cl-) increase inside RBCs, leading to water influx → venous hematocrit is about 3% higher than arterial hematocrit.

Explanation of Other Options:

It facilitates the exchange of HCO3- from plasma into RBCs (Option A): Incorrect. The net movement in systemic capillaries is HCO3- out of RBCs and Cl- in, not the reverse.

It is mediated by carbonic anhydrase located in the plasma (Option C): Incorrect. Carbonic anhydrase is inside RBCs, not in plasma. The exchanger AE1, not carbonic anhydrase, mediates the Cl-/HCO3- exchange.

It reduces venous hematocrit by causing water efflux from RBCs (Option D): Incorrect. Water actually enters RBCs, causing them to swell, so venous hematocrit is slightly higher than arterial hematocrit.

Key Takeaway:

The chloride shift ensures CO2 transport as bicarbonate by exchanging HCO3- out of RBCs for Cl- into RBCs. This leads to higher chloride content and hematocrit in venous blood compared to arterial blood.

choices.text: Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are true, and Reason (R) correctly explains Assertion (A).
Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are true, but Reason (R) does not correctly explain Assertion (A).
Assertion (A) is true, but Reason (R) is false.
Assertion (A) is false, but Reason (R) is true.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Type I pneumocytes cover approximately 95% of the alveolar surface area and serve as the primary lining cells of the alveoli.
Reason (R): Type II pneumocytes, despite covering only about 5% of the alveolar surface area, represent nearly 60% of alveolar epithelial cells and are primarily responsible for surfactant production.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is Option B because although both statements are true, surfactant production by Type II pneumocytes does not explain why Type I pneumocytes cover ~95% of the alveolar surface area.

Pneumocytes:

  • Type I pneumocytes:
    • Flat squamous cells with large cytoplasmic extensions.
    • Cover ~95% of the alveolar surface area.
    • Primary role is gas exchange due to their thin structure.
  • Type II pneumocytes (granular pneumocytes):
    • Cuboidal cells, thicker, and more numerous (~60% of alveolar epithelial cells).
    • Cover only ~5% of alveolar surface area.
    • Contain lamellar bodies that secrete surfactant into alveoli.
    • Surfactant reduces surface tension, preventing alveolar collapse and aiding compliance.
    • Also function in alveolar repair and regeneration of Type I cells.

Key Takeaways:

  • Type I cells: structure → surface coverage for gas exchange.
  • Type II cells: function → surfactant production + alveolar repair.
  • Both cell types are essential, but their functions are independent and complementary.

questions.text: Match the abnormal respiratory patterns listed in Column 1 with their corresponding characteristics/causes in Column 2.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The correct option is D because:
    • Cheyne-Stokes respiration is cyclical with apnea followed by waxing and waning tidal volumes.
    • Biot respiration consists of irregular clusters of deep breaths interrupted by apnea, seen in pontine lesions or opioid intoxication.
    • Kussmaul respiration is deep and labored breathing due to metabolic acidosis (eg, DKA, uremia, salicylate poisoning).
    • Apneustic breathing is characterized by prolonged inspiration followed by inadequate expiration, due to damage in the upper pons.


Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470309/

questions.text: Which wave of the jugular venous pulse corresponds to atrial systole?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The a wave of the jugular venous pulse corresponds to atrial systole, when atrial contraction increases atrial pressure, which is transmitted to the great veins.

Jugular Venous Pulse Waves and Descents:


Explanation of Other Options:

c wave (Option B): Produced by bulging of the tricuspid valve into the atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.

v wave (Option C): Represents rise in atrial pressure due to venous filling against a closed tricuspid valve, just before it opens in diastole.

y descent (Option D): Occurs when the tricuspid valve opens and blood flows from the atrium into the ventricle, causing a fall in atrial pressure.

choices.text: ET-1 is stored in secretory granules and released on stimulation
ETB receptor is specific for endothelin-1 and mediates vasoconstriction
Endothelin-1 levels are increased in systemic hypertension
Big endothelin-1 has about 1% activity compared to endothelin-1

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding endothelin-1 (ET-1) is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is Big endothelin-1 has about 1% activity compared to endothelin-1.

  • Endothelin-1 is synthesized as a 39-amino acid prohormone called big endothelin-1, which has very low intrinsic activity (≈1%).
  • It is converted to active endothelin-1 by the endothelin-converting enzyme.
  • ET-1 acts mainly in a paracrine fashion, mediating vascular tone via ETA and ETB receptors.

Endothelin-1:

  • Storage: Not stored in granules, regulated at transcriptional level.
  • Receptors:
    • ETA receptor: Specific for ET-1, mediates vasoconstriction.
    • ETB receptor: Responds to all three endothelins (ET-1, ET-2, ET-3), may mediate vasodilation.
  • Pathophysiology: ET-1 is not elevated in hypertension, but it is elevated in heart failure and myocardial infarction.
  • Other functions: ET-1 is found in endothelium, kidneys, brain, and participates in tubuloglomerular feedback.

Explanation of Other Options:

ET-1 is stored in secretory granules (Option A): Incorrect. ET-1 is not stored; secretion is regulated at the level of gene transcription.

ETB receptor is specific for endothelin-1 (Option B): Incorrect. ETB receptors bind all three endothelins and can mediate vasodilation.

Endothelin-1 levels are increased in systemic hypertension (Option C): Incorrect. ET-1 is not elevated in hypertension, but it rises in heart failure and post-MI.

choices.text: Decreased peripheral vascular resistance due to baroreceptor inhibition
Compression of veins by raised intrathoracic pressure reducing venous return
Enhanced sympathetic discharge causing tachycardia and vasoconstriction
Reflex bradycardia mediated by baroreceptor activation

questions.text: A 42-year-old man undergoes a cardiovascular autonomic function test involving forced expiration against a closed glottis. His arterial pressure initially rises, then falls during the maneuver, followed by a transient overshoot after release, accompanied by reflex bradycardia. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the fall in arterial pressure during the sustained phase of the maneuver?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The fall in arterial pressure during the sustained phase of the Valsalva maneuver occurs due to high intrathoracic pressure compressing veins, which decreases venous return and cardiac output. This reduced preload leads to a decline in arterial and pulse pressure.

  • At the onset of straining: Arterial pressure rises because the increased intrathoracic pressure is added to the aortic pressure.
  • Sustained phase: Venous return and cardiac output fall, leading to a decline in arterial pressure.
  • Reflex response: Decreased arterial pressure inhibits baroreceptors, causing tachycardia and increased peripheral resistance.
  • Release phase: When the glottis opens, venous return and cardiac output are restored. The blood pressure overshoots above normal, stimulating baroreceptors → reflex bradycardia.

Explanation of Other Options:

Decreased peripheral vascular resistance due to baroreceptor inhibition (Option A): Peripheral resistance actually increases due to sympathetic activation, not decreases.

Enhanced sympathetic discharge causing tachycardia and vasoconstriction (Option C): This is a reflex response secondary to the fall in blood pressure, not the primary cause of pressure fall.

Reflex bradycardia mediated by baroreceptor activation (Option D): Bradycardia occurs only after the maneuver ends when blood pressure overshoots, not during the fall in arterial pressure.

choices.text: At the venular end, capillary hydrostatic pressure exceeds plasma oncotic pressure, favoring filtration into the interstitial space
The interstitial oncotic pressure (πi) usually contributes significantly to fluid reabsorption in most systemic tissues.
Approximately 50% of the fluid filtered at the arteriolar end is normally reabsorbed back into capillaries, with the rest carried away by lymphatics.
About 85% of the filtered fluid is reabsorbed into the capillaries, while the remaining ~15% returns via the lymphatic system.

questions.text: In systemic capillaries, the net movement of fluid is determined by the balance between hydrostatic and oncotic pressures. Considering the Starling forces as described in Ganong, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the dynamics of capillary fluid exchange?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is D, because approximately 24 liters of fluid is filtered daily through capillaries, and about 85% is reabsorbed into them, with the remainder (~15%) returning via the lymphatic system. This balance maintains normal interstitial fluid homeostasis.

Key Points on Starling Forces:

  • Capillary Hydrostatic Pressure (Pc): Pushes fluid out of the capillaries; higher at the arteriolar end (∼37 mmHg) than the venular end (∼17 mmHg).
  • Interstitial Hydrostatic Pressure (Pi): Usually low or slightly negative; opposes Pc when positive.
  • Capillary Oncotic Pressure (πc): Pulls fluid back into capillaries (∼25 mmHg), constant along the capillary.
  • Interstitial Oncotic Pressure (πi): Negligible under normal conditions, thus contributes little to reabsorption.
  • Net effect: Filtration at the arteriolar end, reabsorption at the venular end.

Summary Table: Starling Forces in Capillary Exchange

Explanation of Other Options:

At the venular end, capillary hydrostatic pressure exceeds plasma oncotic pressure, favoring filtration into the interstitial space (Option A): Incorrect, because at the venular end, plasma oncotic pressure (~25 mmHg) exceeds hydrostatic pressure (~17 mmHg), favoring reabsorption rather than filtration.

The interstitial oncotic pressure (πi) usually contributes significantly to fluid reabsorption in most systemic tissues (Option B): Incorrect, since interstitial oncotic pressure is normally negligible and does not contribute significantly to reabsorption.

Approximately 50% of the fluid filtered at the arteriolar end is normally reabsorbed back into capillaries, with the rest carried away by lymphatics (Option C): Incorrect, as it is not 50%-85% is reabsorbed, with only about 15% drained via lymphatics.

choices.text: Naturally occurring anti-A and anti-B IgM antibodies of the mother crossing the placenta
Formation of maternal IgG anti-D antibodies against fetal Rh-positive cells
Persistence of H antigen in the mother, leading to cross-reactivity with fetal antigens
Incompatibility due to ABO system being more severe than Rh incompatibility

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents at 36 weeks of pregnancy. Her blood group is O negative, and her husband is A positive. Indirect Coombs test is positive at high titers. The newborn is at risk of developing hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN). Which of the following best explains the immunological basis behind this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The hemolytic disease of the newborn (erythroblastosis fetalis) most commonly occurs due to Rh incompatibility. When an Rh-negative mother is exposed to Rh-positive fetal RBCs, she produces IgG anti-D antibodies. These IgG antibodies cross the placenta and cause hemolysis of fetal red cells, leading to anemia, jaundice, hydrops fetalis, and kernicterus.

  • Blood Grouping Basics:
    • Blood groups are based on antigens (agglutinogens) on RBC membranes and antibodies (agglutinins) in plasma.
    • ABO system: Determined by terminal sugars added to the H antigen (A = N-acetylgalactosamine, B = galactose, AB = both, O = none).
    • Rh system: Most important antigen is D antigen. Rh-negative individuals develop anti-D antibodies only after exposure to Rh-positive RBCs.
    • Unlike ABO antibodies (IgM, naturally occurring), Rh antibodies are IgG and acquired, making them capable of crossing the placenta.

Explanation of Other Options:

Naturally occurring anti-A and anti-B IgM antibodies of the mother crossing the placenta (Option A): ABO antibodies are mainly IgM, which do not cross the placenta, hence they rarely cause severe HDN.

Persistence of H antigen in the mother, leading to cross-reactivity with fetal antigens (Option C): The H antigen is the precursor for ABO antigens and persists in group O individuals, but it does not cause cross-reactivity leading to hemolytic disease.

Incompatibility due to ABO system being more severe than Rh incompatibility (Option D): ABO incompatibility causes mild jaundice, whereas Rh incompatibility is more severe, often leading to hydrops fetalis and kernicterus.

choices.text: Increased myocardial contractility due to direct thiamine stimulation
Reduced peripheral resistance caused by compensatory vasodilation
Elevated oxygen carrying capacity of blood leading to cardiac overwork
Direct increase in sympathetic drive causing tachycardia

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the mechanism by which thiamine deficiency leads to high-output cardiac failure in beriberi?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) functions as thiamine pyrophosphate, an essential coenzyme in carbohydrate metabolism. In its deficiency, tissues cannot efficiently utilize carbohydrates for energy, leading to increased peripheral vasodilation. This markedly reduces total peripheral resistance (TPR), causing a compensatory rise in venous return and cardiac output, which may double the normal value. Over time, this strain results in high-output cardiac failure seen in beriberi.

  • Key Points:
    • Thiamine is required for oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate and α-keto acids.
    • Deficiency → impaired carbohydrate metabolism → decreased ATP generation.
    • Local tissue hypometabolism → release of vasodilator substances → ↓ TPR.
    • ↓ TPR → ↑ venous return & ↑ cardiac output → high-output heart failure.
    • Additional features: peripheral edema, polyneuritis, muscle weakness, GI symptoms.

Explanation of Other Options:

Increased myocardial contractility due to direct thiamine stimulation (Option A): Incorrect, thiamine deficiency weakens rather than strengthens the heart muscle.

Elevated oxygen carrying capacity of blood leading to cardiac overwork (Option C): Incorrect, thiamine deficiency does not increase oxygen carrying capacity; instead, it decreases metabolic utilization of oxygen.

Direct increase in sympathetic drive causing tachycardia (Option D): Incorrect, cardiac output increase is secondary to low peripheral resistance, not due to primary sympathetic overactivity.

choices.text: Depolarisation depends mainly on slow inward Ca²⁺ currents rather than fast Na⁺ currents
Rapid inactivation of K⁺ channels prevent a steep upstroke
The more negative resting potential enhances threshold delay
Both Na⁺ and Ca²⁺ channels contribute equally to Phase 0

questions.text: Compared with ventricular myocytes, why do the action potentials of sinoatrial (SA) nodal cells demonstrate a slower rate of depolarisation during Phase 0?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In ventricular myocytes, the rapid Phase 0 upstroke is caused by opening of fast voltage-gated Na⁺ channels, producing a sharp spike in depolarisation.
  • In contrast, SA nodal cells lack functional fast Na⁺ channels, and their Phase 0 depends instead on slow inward Ca²⁺ currents (primarily through L-type Ca²⁺ channels).
  • Because Ca²⁺ entry is slower compared to Na⁺ entry, the depolarisation upstroke is gradual rather than sharp.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Rapid inactivation of K⁺ channels (Option B): K⁺ channels are important for repolarisation (Phase 3), not for the upstroke. Their inactivation does not explain the slow Phase 0.

The more negative resting potential enhances threshold delay (Option C): SA nodal cells actually have a less negative maximum diastolic potential (~-60 mV) compared with ventricular myocytes (~-90 mV). This does influence Na⁺ channel inactivation, but the main cause of the slow upstroke is reliance on Ca²⁺ currents, not the resting potential itself.

Both Na⁺ and Ca²⁺ channels contribute equally to Phase 0 (Option D): Incorrect. Only Ca²⁺ currents drive Phase 0 depolarisation in nodal cells, as Na⁺ channels are absent or inactivated.

Key Takeaway:
The absence of fast Na⁺ channels in SA and AV nodal cells explains why their depolarisation is slower and dependent on Ca²⁺ entry via L-type channels, unlike the sharp Na⁺-driven spike seen in ventricular myocytes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man receives intravenous nitro-glycerine during management of unstable angina. Soon after infusion, he develops marked hypotension along with bradycardia. This response is most likely due to activation of which reflex pathway?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Bezold-Jarisch reflex is a cardioinhibitory reflex initiated by mechanoreceptors and chemoreceptors in the ventricular walls (especially inferoposterior LV), transmitted via the vagus nerve. When there is sudden reduction in venous return or excessive ventricular stretch (e.g., nitrates, spinal anesthesia, inferior MI), the reflex causes:

  • Hypotension (peripheral vasodilation)
  • Bradycardia (vagal stimulation)
  • Coronary vasodilation

This is paradoxical because instead of compensatory tachycardia (as in baroreceptor reflex), the patient gets bradycardia.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Bainbridge reflex (Option A): Triggered by right atrial stretch receptors due to increased venous return → results in tachycardia, not bradycardia.

Cushing's reflex (Option C): Seen in raised intracranial pressure → triad of hypertension, bradycardia, irregular respiration. The bradycardia here is secondary to baroreceptor response, not ventricular receptors.

Baroreceptor reflex (Option D): In response to acute rise in blood pressure, arterial baroreceptors (carotid sinus, aortic arch) cause reflex bradycardia. In this case, bradycardia occurs despite hypotension, ruling this out.

Key Takeaway:

The Bezold-Jarisch reflex produces the triad of bradycardia, hypotension, and coronary vasodilation in response to ventricular receptor stimulation, classically seen with nitrates or inferior wall MI.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with gradually worsening fatigue and ankle swelling. On examination, elevated jugular venous pressure is noted. The JVP tracing shows absent "a" waves and prominent irregular "v" waves. Which of the following is the most likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In tricuspid regurgitation, regurgitant flow into the right atrium during systole produces giant "v" waves (systolic prominence) with loss of "x" descent.
  • The "a" wave may be absent if right atrial contraction is ineffective against an incompetent valve.
  • JVP becomes systolic-dominant rather than diastolic-dominant.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Tricuspid stenosis (Option A): Causes giant "a" wave due to forceful atrial contraction against a stenotic valve, not prominent "v" waves.

Complete heart block (Option C): Produces cannon "a" wave from atrial contraction against closed tricuspid valve during AV dissociation.

Constrictive pericarditis (Option D): Produces a prominent "y" descent (rapid filling wave) and "square root" sign, not giant "v" waves.

Key Takeaway:

  • "a" wave → atrial contraction (giant in TS, cannon in AV dissociation, absent in AF).
  • "v" wave → atrial filling (giant in TR).
  • "y" descent → rapid ventricular filling (prominent in CP).

choices.text: Persistent stimulation of carotid body chemoreceptors due to hypoxemia
Direct suppression of peripheral chemoreceptor activity by central chemoreceptors
Reduced excitatory drive from central chemoreceptors due to fall in PaCO₂

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with worsening dyspnoea. His arterial blood gases show PaO₂ = 68 mmHg (low), PaCO₂ = 30 mmHg (low), and pH = 7.47 (respiratory alkalosis). Despite persistently low oxygen levels, his respiratory drive returns closer to normal after some time.
What is the most likely explanation for this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Low PaO₂ initially stimulates peripheral chemoreceptors (carotid bodies), leading to hyperventilation.
  • Hyperventilation causes a fall in PaCO₂, which reduces hydrogen ion concentration in CSF.
  • Central chemoreceptors are the dominant drivers of respiration; when PaCO₂ falls, their stimulatory input decreases.
  • This loss of central drive overrides the peripheral hypoxic drive, so overall ventilation returns toward normal despite persistent hypoxemia.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Persistent stimulation of carotid body chemoreceptors due to hypoxemia (Option A): Incorrect because while carotid bodies sense low O₂, their effect is weaker compared to central chemoreceptors, so cannot maintain increased ventilation once central drive is reduced.

Direct suppression of peripheral chemoreceptor activity by central chemoreceptors (Option B): Incorrect because there is no direct inhibitory control; rather, it is the reduced PaCO₂ lowering central chemoreceptor activity that diminishes overall ventilation.

All of the above (Option D): Incorrect because only the fall in PaCO₂ (Option C) explains the normalization of breathing.

Key Takeaway:

In COPD or hypoxic states, low PaO₂ triggers hyperventilation, but the resulting low PaCO₂ reduces central chemoreceptor drive, normalizing ventilation despite persistent hypoxemia.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, but R is true

questions.text:
Assertion (A): In COPD, the total lung capacity (TLC) is increased.
Reason (R): Air trapping due to loss of elastic recoil leads to increased residual volume (RV).
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • COPD causes obstructive ventilatory defect with increased compliance and loss of elastic recoil.
  • This results in air trapping and a marked increase in residual volume (RV).
  • Because TLC = RV + VC, an elevated RV leads to an increase in total lung capacity.
  • Hence, both the assertion and reason are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Option B (Both true, but R not correct explanation): Incorrect, because air trapping is exactly the mechanism by which TLC increases.

Option C (A true, R false): Incorrect, as the reason is not false; RV increase is well-established in COPD.

Option D (A false, R true): Incorrect, since TLC is indeed increased in COPD.

Key Takeaway

  • COPD: ↑RV, ↑FRC, ↑TLC; ↓VC, ↓IC, ↓ERV
  • Mechanism: Air trapping + loss of elastic recoil

choices.text: It is released from the juxtaglomerular cells of the kidney
Its most potent stimulus for release is hypoxi
Its therapeutic use in CKD-related anaemia decreases risk of hypertension

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding erythropoietin is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Erythropoietin is primarily produced by peritubular interstitial cells in the renal cortex and outer medulla. The most powerful trigger for its secretion is hypoxia, which stabilizes hypoxia-inducible factor-1α (HIF-1α), leading to transcriptional upregulation of the EPO gene. The hormone acts on erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, stimulating their proliferation and differentiation, thereby increasing red blood cell mass.

  • EPO source: Primarily the kidney (peritubular interstitial cells), with about 10% produced by the liver.
  • Main stimulus: Hypoxia is the most potent trigger for EPO secretion.
  • Key regulator: Hypoxia-Inducible Factor-1 (HIF-1) activates EPO gene transcription under low oxygen tension.
  • Other stimulants: Norepinephrine, epinephrine, prostaglandins, and androgens can increase EPO but are less potent compared to hypoxia.
  • Function: EPO acts on the bone marrow to stimulate erythropoiesis (RBC proliferation and differentiation).

Explanation of Incorrect Options

  1. Released from JG cells: Incorrect. Renin is secreted by JG cells; EPO is secreted by peritubular interstitial fibroblast-like cells.
  2. Acts via GPCRs: Incorrect. EPO receptors are JAK-STAT-associated tyrosine kinase receptors, not G-protein-coupled.
  3. Decreases risk of hypertension: Incorrect. High EPO levels or therapy can actually increase risk of hypertension due to raised haematocrit and vascular resistance.

Key Takeaway

  • Site of release: Peritubular interstitial cells (kidney)
  • Stimulus: Hypoxia (most potent)
  • Mechanism: JAK-STAT receptor pathway
  • Clinical: Used in anemia of CKD; adverse effect includes hypertension

questions.text:
A 6-year-old child presents with recurrent bacterial and fungal infections. Neutrophil count is normal, but nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) test is negative. The defect is most likely due to impaired generation of superoxide radicals during respiratory burst.
Which enzyme deficiency best explains this finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • NADPH oxidase is essential for initiating the respiratory burst in neutrophils.
  • It converts oxygen into superoxide (O₂⁻), the precursor of other reactive oxygen species (ROS).
  • Deficiency leads to chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). Patients have recurrent bacterial and fungal infections with granuloma formation.
  • The NBT test or DHR (dihydrorhodamine) flow cytometry is used diagnostically; both are abnormal in CGD.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • Myeloperoxidase deficiency (Option A): Leads to absent hypochlorous acid (HOCl) formation. Patients are often asymptomatic or mildly affected; NBT test remains normal.
  • Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (Option C): Causes hemolytic anemia under oxidative stress (drugs, fava beans, infections). While NADPH levels are affected, it primarily manifests as hemolysis, not isolated phagocyte dysfunction.
  • Defect in lysosomal acid hydrolase (Option D): Seen in lysosomal storage diseases (e.g., I-cell disease), not in neutrophil respiratory burst defects.

Key Takeaway:

  • NADPH oxidase deficiency → failure of respiratory burst → recurrent infections + negative NBT test.
  • Myeloperoxidase deficiency → impaired HOCl formation → usually mild susceptibility.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old male presents with a history of chronic nasal obstruction and recurrent productive cough since childhood. Examination reveals coarse crepitations in both lung fields. His chest X-ray is given below.

Which of the following conditions best explains his clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Kartagener syndrome is a type of primary ciliary dyskinesia caused by mutations in dynein arms of cilia, leading to immotile cilia.
  • Defective cilia impair mucociliary clearance, causing recurrent sinusitis and bronchiectasis.
  • Ciliary dysfunction during embryogenesis affects organ positioning → situs inversus (seen on X-ray as dextrocardia).
  • In males, immotile spermatozoa due to defective flagella lead to infertility, which is commonly associated though not part of the classical triad.
  • Classical triad: sinusitis, bronchiectasis, situs inversus.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Cystic fibrosis (Option A): Causes bronchiectasis and infertility, but mechanism is due to thick mucus (CFTR mutation), not immotile cilia; situs inversus is not seen.

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (Option C): Causes panacinar emphysema and liver disease, but situs inversus and infertility are absent.

Chronic granulomatous disease (Option D): NADPH oxidase defect causes recurrent infections due to impaired killing by neutrophils; situs inversus and infertility are not features.

Key Takeaway:

Kartagener syndrome = dynein mutation → immotile cilia → triad of sinusitis, bronchiectasis, situs inversus, with additional infertility due to immotile sperm.

choices.text: Sarcomere length has exceeded the optimal range, reducing cross-bridge formation
Excessive afterload prevents ejection despite increased end-diastolic volume
Reduced preload limits actin-myosin overlap, decreasing force of contraction
The Frank-Starling mechanism is independent of sarcomere length

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of dilated cardiomyopathy is admitted with progressive dyspnea. On echocardiography, the left ventricular end-diastolic volume is markedly increased, but stroke volume is reduced. Which of the following best explains this finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In dilated cardiomyopathy, the heart is operating on the descending limb of the Frank-Starling curve.
  • Sarcomeres are overstretched, so actin-myosin overlap is reduced, and cross-bridge cycling becomes inefficient.
  • As a result, stroke volume decreases despite very high end-diastolic volume (preload).
  • This is the physiological limit of the Frank-Starling law: increased stretch improves contraction only up to an optimal sarcomere length (~2.2 µm). Beyond this, contractility falls.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Excessive afterload prevents ejection despite increased end-diastolic volume (Option B): Increased afterload does decrease stroke volume, but the stem highlights preload-related failure, not afterload.

Reduced preload limits actin-myosin overlap, decreasing force of contraction (Option C): Preload is not reduced here; it is abnormally high in dilated ventricles.

The Frank-Starling mechanism is independent of sarcomere length (Option D): Incorrect, because the Frank-Starling law is fundamentally based on sarcomere length-tension relationship.

Key Takeaway:

Frank-Starling law applies only up to an optimal sarcomere length. In dilated cardiomyopathy, sarcomeres exceed this limit, causing reduced stroke volume despite high preload.

questions.text: A young healthy volunteer undergoes rapid intravenous infusion of 500 mL saline. Within minutes, there is an observed increase in heart rate without significant change in mean arterial pressure. Which reflex best explains this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Bainbridge reflex is triggered by stretch receptors in the walls of the right atrium and vena cavae.
  • Increased venous return (e.g., rapid saline infusion, right atrial engorgement) causes activation of these low-pressure mechanoreceptors.
  • Afferents travel via the vagus nerve to the medullary centers.
  • The efferent response is increased heart rate (tachycardia) mediated by inhibition of vagal tone and increased sympathetic activity to the SA node.
  • Importantly, this reflex helps match cardiac output to venous return.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Baroreceptor reflex (Option a): Activated by arterial pressure changes at carotid sinus/aortic arch. Maintains BP, not atrial filling.

Bezold-Jarisch reflex (Option c): Triggered by ventricular mechanoreceptors (esp. LV). Produces paradoxical bradycardia, hypotension, and vasodilation - opposite to Bainbridge reflex.

Cushing reflex (Option d): Raised intracranial pressure → hypertension, bradycardia, irregular breathing (Cushing's triad). Not related to atrial stretch.

Key Takeaway:

The Bainbridge reflex is a tachycardic response to increased venous return and right atrial stretch, helping maintain balance between inflow and outflow of the heart.
